Entry.0:
JANUARY, 
1916 
1917

Monday 1st
New Year's Day had a days spell.

Tuesday (2)
Physical drill before breakfast afterwards rifle inspection, afternoon had a spell.

Wednesday (3)
Reveille 6-30 moved out of Dernancourt. 9-15 passed through Heilly, arrived Flanvillersmidday halted for the day.

Thursday (4)
Left Flanvillers early passed Pont Noyelle and Allanvillearrived and billetted Cardonettewet and dirty village.



January, 

Friday (5)
Morning rifle drillafternoon route marchnightime went to Allanville.

Saturday (6)
Went on Dental parade all day Dentist.

Sunday (7)
Morning church paradeafternoon went to City of Amiensreturned @ night.

January, 

Monday (8)
Bayonet drill in morningafternoon usual platoon drill.

Tuesday (9)
Ditto

Wednesday 2 (10)
Same Drill.
Entry.1:
(11)
Bayonet drill morning afterwards went to Amiensreturned @ night.

January
Entry.2:
(12)
Fatigue filling in trenches Rainville.

Saturday (13)
Left Cardonette morning arrived La Hoyeause after dinner.

Sunday (14)
Left La Hoyeausi morning in a snowstormarrived Dernancourt after dinnerstayed the night.passed several battalions on there way out. for a spell.

January 

Monday (15)
Left Dernancourt on the way to trenchesarrived Adelaide Camp midday very cold night.

Tuesday (16) 
Left Adelaide Camp midday for trenches got turned back Trônes Wood.snowed heavy during night.

Wednesday (17)
Various fatigues during day Left Trônes Wood with gum boots for firing linearrived back nine o'clock.

Thursday (18)
Fatigue.

January 

Friday (19)
Fatigue all day carrying packs and officers luggage.

Saturday (20)
Fatigue around camp.

Sunday (21)
Fatigue battalion came out of trenches.

January 

Monday (22)
Went up to Eskimo Dump of fatiguehad a look inside a Tankcameback and carried blanket and packs to Montauban.

Tuesday (23)
Montauban camp all day fearfully cold.

Wednesday (24)
Still @ Montauban fell in morning rifle inspection enemy aeroplanes flew over camp.
Entry.3:
(25)
Fell in morning and dismissedafternoon went through tear shell test with gas respirator.



January 

Friday (26)
Moved down to Quarry did fatigue work.

Saturday (27)
Same thing.

Sunday (28)
Still on Fatigue bitterly cold.



January 

Monday (29)
Cooks fatigue bad feet.

Tuesday 
Cooks fatigue.

Wednesday 
Cooks fatigue

Thursday 
General Fatigue carrying water in sand bags.frozen over had to chop with axes to get water for tea.

February 

Friday 
Fatigue Mametz Wood.

Saturday 
Fatigue again.

Sunday 
Moved back to Fricourt Brigade Camp.

February
Entry.4:
Cooks fatigue afternoon rifle and bayonet inspection.
Bayonet drill and company drill morning and afternoon.
Entry.5:
Bayonet and squad drill in morning, afternoon inspection in fighting order, afterwards went into Albert. Hut caught fire close by three men burnt to death.

Wednesday 
Moved out for the trenches in morning arrived Delville Wood about two went over to Sugar Mill met old mate in 53rd Batt.

Thursday 
Detailed off to Drying Shed.

February 

Friday 
Did nothing

Saturday 
Nothing.
Carried rations to Headquarters Needle trench.

Sunday 
Carried socks to Swiss trench.

February 

Monday 
Carried socks to Swiss Trench, very muddy and boggy.

Tuesday 
Carried socks to Rose Trench and Millison's Son Dug Out.

Wednesday 
Same as previous day.

Thursday 
Carried socks to Headquarters Front line slush and mud knee deep.

February 

Friday 
Carried socks to Needle Trench nightime Battalion not out of line, went back to Delville Wood.

Saturday 
Went up to Needle Trench morning, afternoon went to Trônes Wood for rations.

Sunday 
Came back from Delville Wood to Trônes Wood joined up Company.

February 

Monday 
Shifted from Trônes Wood to Adelaide Camp, Montauban.

Tuesday 
Fell in on parade in morning did nothing else.

Wednesday 
Had a spell saw kite balloon fall in pieces.

Thursday 
Mess orderly, went for bath to Fricourt in afternoon.

February 

Friday 
Issued with new pay books, shifted in afternoon to Trônes Wood. Nightime alarm raised, ordered to be ready to go to front line any moment in fighting order.

Saturday 
Had a spell all day, nightime gas guard midnight till half past two. Two gas alarms raised during night.

Sunday 
Packed ready to move off to line then ordered to stand by finally
came
 ordered to remain @ Trônes Wood.

February - March 

Monday 
Snowed during night, went up to Ginchy Dump on fatigue pushing trucks to and from Needle Dump.

Tuesday 
At Montauban did nothing all
day
 morning attended lecture on compass and maps afternoon.

Wednesday 
At Montaubaun did nothing only mess orderly.

Thursday 
Drill morning and afternoon. Firied fifteen rounds @ musketry class morning.

March 

Friday 
Drill morning, afternoon extended order work nightime guard on cook-house from seven till nine thirty o'clock.

Saturday 
Morning practicsed artillery formation, afternoon rifle exercise.

Sunday 
Received Christmas parcel afternoon left for trenches arrived subsidary line dusk stayed there that night.



March 

Monday 
Left subsidary line about eight o'clock. Arrived village of Ligny-Thilloy did duty on No. 14 Post that night. Dug-outcorner of garden good post.

Tuesday 
Stayed in dug out all day that night called out. Company advanced 400 yards and dug trenches, met with no opposition.

Wednesday 
Kept down in trench all day. Night time midnight A and Company went to to enemy lines but after severe machine gun fire had to retire, one killed couple wounded.

Thursday 
Stayed in trench again all day bitterly cold and miserable all day, night time patrol went out and cut enemy's barbed wire.

March 

Friday 
Returned about nine o'clock night arrived back subsidary line early morning. 
30th Batt. entered Bapaume.

Saturday 
Had a spell for the day 30th Battalion entered Bapaume.

Sunday 
Moved up from Subsidary line to a trench near Lingy Thilluoy , camped in a big underground enemy dug out.
Entry.6:
Monday 13
Enlisted Town Hall, Sydney, accepted Dec. 16
wh
 went Casula Camp 17, sworn in 18, nine weeks then went Melbourne reinforce 31st Batt. came from A Coy 20th N.S.W.

Tuesday 14
Left Melbourne A.68 "S.S. Anchises" for the front, good crowd @ wharf. Sailed about one o'clock. Paid the same day£3-10, wrote letter to mate also Mother.

Wednesday 15
At Sea, not too well.

Thursday 16
Arrived Outer Harbour, Adelaide about 7 when for route march Largs Bay, Adelaide. Troops came aboard same day. Several missed the boat, good time Largs Bay.



March 1916

Friday 17
In the Australian Bight, very calm.

Saturday 18
On guard not too well ship pitching a bit, bath sized ship passed 6-30.

Sunday 19
Off guard, argument about breakfast got it in saloon in the end. Still a bit crook.
Sent£3-10 to Sydney 16/3/16, £1 debt£2-10 bank.
Entry.8:
20
At sea very smooth feeling bonzer.
Entry.9: At sea still smooth still good.
Entry.11:
23
At sea still very smooth, eating good feel good.
Entry.12: At sea lovely weather getting warm, dressed full uniform and kit in afternoon. Ship like Warship came and signalled at night then disappeared.
Entry.13:
At sea still lovely weather feeling good saw boxing. Afternoon ship passed late at night, getting warm.

Sunday 26
On guard again, very warm, very hot down below.
Entry.15:
27
On guard till ten getting still warmer.
Entry.17:
29
Crossed the line. Father Neptune sports indulged in, rained very heavy, missed getting christened.
Entry.18:
30
Still @ sea, very hot, got paid£1 looking forward to reaching Colombo.
Entry.20:
Arrived Colombo about seven a.m., beautiful place to look @ from harbour, dissappointed @ not being allowed ashore in afternoon. Reported 128 in shade, hot as you lilke.

Saturday 1 April
Wentashore on route march through streets to Barracks and back again to ship, never saw much of it only principal streets and some buildings.
Entry.21:
2
Left port about six, saw 
buri
 first burial at sea same morning, sea lovely and smooth, saw two
shapes
 ships p.m. Some missed boat, one badly hurt Colombo. Getting sick and tired of trip tucker only tucker.
Entry.22: At sea lovely and calm as usual.
Entry.23: On guard again third time on trip two till six number twelve post, fight started below finished in ring.
Entry.24: Came off guard on from four a.m. till six a.m., still warm.
Entry.25: Start same old thing, tucker getting rotten. Saw challenge boxing contest afternoon.
Entry.26:
Boat drill morning
bar
 parade with lifebelts on, large steamer passed very close. Tug of war afternoon. N.S.W. beat S.A. and Light horse teams.
Entry.27: Caught and passed steamer during night, saw fight in ring. N.S.W. Tug of war team were defeated by Victoria.
Entry.28: Passed what looked like Aden early morning about 2, saw light house and searchlight, daylight saw long looked for land Arabian Coast, P & O steamer passed 9 a.m., then saw African coast on other side, looked very nice then passed Perrim in afternoon while looking and tall light house supposed to be in the Red Sea.
Entry.29: Well in Red Sea fairly cool large French steamer caught and passed us also passed some more vessels during day, nice and cool weather expected different.
Entry.30:
Ship like
Orsova
 caught and passed us, did bayonet drill morning, paraded afternoon with everything that was issued, looking forward to landing in Egypt and getting a square feed.
Entry.31: Passed several ships. Ship like Orsova passed, sea lovely and smooth, paid 10/6 and issued with a pay book. Hospital ship passed at night lit up also large steamer.
Entry.32: Got up early expecting to see Suez but so far 6.30 not in sight, passed boat very close. Arrived Suez afternoon, 20 boats anchored, reported not to land till next day. Dust storm came up completely obliterated land. Tucker getting unbearable.
Entry.33: Still aboard all day latest report going ashore to-morrow then going up into desert, looking forward to getting off. As usual half fed again, row about tucker tea time, same result nothing done.
Entry.34: Left boat when aboard train 2-30, arrived Tel-el-Kebir sunset, very big camp, paraded about for blankets and had first taste of bully beef and biscuits.
Entry.35: Attended church parade very hot, walked about a bit saw Casula tent mate, also mate from Carinda, visited cemetry of men who fell in Tel-el-Kebir battle 1882 at night wrote letters in Y.M.C.A. Tent.
Entry.36: Drafted into another tent and mess table, fairly warm, did a lot of parading about also full Kit inspection.
Entry.37: Went route march before breakfast paraded after full marching orders, nice cool day and cold wind at night.
Entry.38: Afternoon built paraphet around tents, night time went out night training, morning usual chill.
Entry.39: Went for route march along Tel-el-Kebir trenches afterwards pulled equipment apart and put it together again. Applied for leave to go to Cairo.
Entry.40: Church parade morning, no drill afterwards but fell in and got summer issue and helmet and put on same. Tent in lines quarintened for diptheria.
Entry.41: Morning physical and squad drill, nothing afterwards, cricket match played. Saw a couple of friends, wrote a letter to A. Owers.
Entry.42: Fatigue duty all day rose at five and marched about all day doing practically nothing only growling. Wrote letter to E. Cambell, Carinda, Walgett, N.S.W., Australia.
Entry.43: Fatigue work all day saw dust up @ night. Troops from S.A. and W.A. arrived.
Entry.44: Anzac Day kept up got no dinner, went and had a look at sports afternoon, open air concert and boxing and wrestling very good, no drill at all that Day, applied for leave to visit Cairo for Saturday.
Entry.45: Drill as usual. Tasmania and Vic. troops arrived, another dust up. Canteen wrecked and partly burnt.
Entry.46:
Route march morning along Tel-el-Kebir trenches, afterwards inspection by C.O. Company, did pack drill afternoon for bad fitting packs
at
 then usual drill, hardly any tucker that day. Another shop wrecked @ night.
Entry.47: Usual drill all day. Night operations at night. Tent mate carried away sick. Another dust up shops burnt out and looted pickets called out.
Entry.49: Usual church parade in morning, picked for guard and went on in Sunday afternoon at No. 2 Australian Hospital. Picket sent to Abbassa and Cairo also twenty-six on 48 hours rations.
Entry.50: On guard till five o'clock in afternoon.
Entry.51: Red tape drill uniform ordered. Route march before breakfast.
Entry.52: Usual drill, route march at night. Extended order in morning.
Entry.53: Route march before breakfast, usual drill day, some paid some not.
Entry.54: Paid£3-12-10 before breakfast, after breakfast trench digging, afternoon enoculated against cholera then usual drill, after tea night operations, lecture in afternoon.
Entry.55: Drill in morning then picked for picket, mounted picket afternoon with fixed bayonets and ball cartridge round picture show.
Entry.56: Aeroplane flew over camp morning came off picket in afternoon four o'clock.
Entry.57: Inspection by C.O. morning, afternoon extended order drill, wrote two letters home at night.
Entry.58: Usual drill morning, afternoon march, night time troop trains left for France.
Entry.59: Picked for guard, instructed in rifle drill in morning, afternoon mounted guard four o'clock number six post quarter master guard.
Entry.60: On guard came off four o'clock, night time visited Egyptian village.
Entry.61: Usual drill morning, 77 changed in fourth . Enoculated in afternoon, night operations afterwards.
Entry.62: Got days leave to go to Cairo, visited Cairo, Citadel and other places, walked and rode round city, very nice but dirty place and narrow streets, return home 7-15 train.
Entry.63: Off duty all day attended Church parade met cousin going to Serdvia afternoon.
Entry.64: Started on Musketry, dust storm in afternoon.
Entry.65: Shifted Camp to another part of Camp, red hot day.
Entry.66: Met a lot of mates from 20th Battalion, alsoanother mate.
Entry.67: Musketry in morning. Afternoon went in to Cairo as escort duty, very hot day.
Entry.68: Came back to Tel-el-Kebir with 23 prisoners from Kasr-er-nil Barracks, Cairo, very crook afternoon, got paid at night£1-0-7, also inspection hats given back.
Entry.69: Before and after breakfast musketry. No drill afternoon, met E. Johnson nightime.
Entry.70: Church parade morning in picture show, afternoon attended military funeral of a Corporal from 19th Battalion. Drew Prince Bardolph in 25 Piastres Sweep on Sydney Cup during week.
Entry.71: Musketry from 5 a.m. till 8 a.m., again after breakfast and dinner, night time went to pictures.
Entry.73: Musketry before and after breakfast, holiday afternoon on account of Empire Day.
Entry.75: Musketry and trench work morning after guard @ No. 1 Quartermasters, mounted guard about half-past seven.
Entry.76: Came off guard about seven alone done nothing all day, troops including old mates left for England at night.
Entry.77:
Went to Cairo on escort duty got leave from 3 p.m. till 10 p.m. visited Heliopolis and saw sights of Cairo. Tea Y.M.C.A.

May -
Entry.78: Left Kasr-er-nil barracks escort duty with prisoners, one escaped, Zag Zig fired on by officer without effect.
Entry.79: Three hours route march then went Cairo escort again, got five hours leave. Visited Sultan Hassid and Coronation Mosques, also through inside Cathedral.
Entry.80: Left Barracks with prioners took tour out to Serapheum got there dusk after walking from Serapheum Railway.
Entry.81: Left Serapheum for Rail Head in a motor train with three prisoners, back same day had a swim in Suez Canal, arrived back Tel-el-Kebir about half past night night.
Entry.82: Paid£2-0-0 morning, afternoon extended order drill.
Entry.83: Morning usual drill after breakfast, muster roll call of C Company, afternoon nothing went walk up to 53rd lines.
Entry.84: Church parade before breakfast nothing doing remainder of day, severe dust storm afternoon, saw old friend at Night.
Entry.85: Aroused daylight to pack up ready to go to France, did so, waited all day remainder of fifth and six of 31st left for England that night.
Entry.88: Officers Mess attended Muster Roll in morning.
Entry.89: Officers mess breakfast then shifted to the other end of camp.
Entry.90: Morning fatigue work afternoon nothing went Military funeral same evening @ six.
Entry.91: Church parade in morning nothing doing all day, shifted camp about 5-30 in morning
Entry.93: Morning parade sick got medicine three times a day for three days.
Entry.95: Sick parade three times afternoon drill.
Entry.96: Before breakfast usual drill new hours five till seven, afternoon route march.
Entry.97: Usual drill before breakfast after that nothing all day.
Entry.98: Church parade morning then day off.
Entry.99: Morning usual drill afternoon roll call and got ready to march out, fell in @ seven, marched out of Tel-el-Kebir @ quarter to twelve after 9 weeks 2 days and went aboard train.
Entry.100: Train left 1-45 arrived Alexandria about eight, went aboard S.S. Huntsend about ten stayed aboard all day, crowed out no room A.25.
Entry.101: Laying out in No. 2 Harbour all day. Transports Royal George, Caledonian and another all loaded waiting to move off.
Entry.102: Transport moved off while we were having breakfast 7-15. After getting out destroyer came and escorted us zig zaging in front. Another transport just to hand.
Entry.103: At sea fairly smooth, met an old school mate afternoon.
Entry.104: Morning usual parade of aft deck. Afternoon and night guard on 21 Post.
Entry.105: On guard until 4 in afternoon then went off. Ship turned in to Malta and dropped anchor in a nice looking bay about nine mile from chief harbour. Four more transports already in harbour which was well protected by forts.
Entry.106: Had a couple of good swims in St. Pauls Bay during the day, usual fall in in the morning left port in company with other transports and escorts @ 7 p.m.
Entry.107: Passed convict island in the morning, sea fairly smooth.
Entry.108: Passed barge, islands supposed to be Corsica and Sardenia, looking forward to arriving in France. Sea getting a bit rough, strong wind.
Entry.109: Arrived Marseilles daylight anchored out in harbor until late in evening then moved in to wharf. Another transport ahead of us doing same.
Entry.111:
Got on shore afternoon and evening wharf grounds guarded as leave Marseilles declared out of bounds.

Saturday 1 July
Left Marseilles morning 7 oclock travelled all day lovely scenery en route, passed city of Lyons 12 @ night.
Entry.112:
Still travelling all day through lovely country fairly comfortable good rations served good receptions everywhere along line, people cheering all time stopping twice to eat up, went within a few miles of Paris then stopped for a couple of hours all dissappointed at not going on to Paris. Big crowd collected and sang Marseillase and G.S. the King, also presented flowers.

25965 Rifle
Entry.113: Travelling until late in evening and arrived at camp @ Etaples, lot of Imperial troops camped. During day passed several Hospital trains full of wounder also saw three hospital punts.
Entry.114: Morning kit inspection afternoon rifle practice, tucker very light.
Entry.115: Morning rifle practice afternoon same. Bull ring instruction in bayonet and rifle work till 8 oclock, tucker very light.
Entry.116: Morning inspection by a General, afternoon on bayonet and bomb instruction at bull ring.
Entry.117: Morning it rained, fell in couple of times gas lecture in afternoon, issued with gas helmets and paid twenty francs.
Entry.118: Morning fell in then dismissed, same in afternoon also water turned off no wash till afternoon. Visited Paris Plage afternoon with Tommy had a good time, very pretty place of sea front.
Entry.119: Morning church parade afterwards dismissed for the day, wrote letters afternoon, night time went to the pictures.
Entry.120: Morning went for route march, afternoon rifle drill.
Entry.121: Morning bull ring instruction, afternoon send£7-10 to Sydney.
Entry.122: Three hours rifle drill in morning, afternoon fatigue duty in village of Etaples. Stayed in village till 8 p.m.
Entry.123: Morning inspection in drill at the bull ring lectureafternoon on conduct of the brigade by Lt. Adams.
Entry.124: Morning drill for a while afternoon went through gas and tear shell experience at the bull ring.
Entry.126: Issued with some shortages, went and had a look @cemetry afternoon.
Entry.127: Rifle drill morning and afternoon went to Etaples afternoon.
Entry.128: Another issue of clothes went to Bull ring afternoon.
Entry.129: Shooting @ rifle range afternoon guard. Saw large dirigible pass over camp late in evening, birthday.
Entry.130: Morning inspected by N.Z. Major, transferred to Entrenching Battalion, afternoon usual drill issued with boots.
Entry.131: Inspected by General in morning, afternoon got ready to move out to the front.
Entry.132: Left Etaples camp 4 o'clock for the front, arrived @ Steenwerck. Marched through Sailly arrived at Bac-St. Amour about 5, saw aeroplanes bombarded, heard battalion cut up.
Entry.133: Fell in couple of times in morning, after dinner drafted in A Coy, got rations and marched down to Battalion and got billeted in an old weaving factory. Not much noise from line late in afternoonsaw aeroplane bombarded with shells from enemys lines.
Entry.134: Still in billets @ Bac-St-Amour, drafted into section of companies. Paid forty francs.
Entry.135: Morning cooks fatigue, afternoon fatigue work up near firing line. For the first time was in sight of the guns.
Entry.136: Fatigue duty main firing line, saw German trenches, night time went route march up close to the trenches.
Entry.137: Went to baths had a bogey got a change clean clothes, night time gas alarm midnight.
Entry.138: Left billet Bac-St-Maur did a day coal lumping shifted to newbillet said billet being an old barn about hundred in it. Barn not too clean. Saw aeroplane bombardment.
Entry.139: Out at daylight went up to firing line fatigue duty York Avenue blown in. Afternoon witnessed shelling of church in village by the Germans.
Entry.140:
Up @ trenches as usual for half day doing fatigue duty making dug outs.

July -
Entry.141:
Morning fatigue work @ front line saw man killed by sniper, relieved 29th Battalion @ night in trenches got shelled doing so. Put on gas and aeroplane guard afternoon gas guard at night.

Tuesday
Entry.142: Gas guard B.H.Qts. got shelled going in from shrapnel and machine gun fire, came off guard and went into firing line fired first shot at square heads about twelve.
Entry.143: Usual trench work. Trenches shelled by high explosive shells dinner time saw aeroplane duel at dusk neither machines damaged.
Entry.144: Usual trench business supports again shelled. Afternoon shifted from firing line to supports. Then brought back and sent out to No Mans Land with two others on listening post duty for four hours.
Entry.145: Had a days spell at @ night went on gas guard at post @ support trench.
Entry.146: Guard until six in evening saw aeroplane brought down landed safely in our own lines, reported another one down further along line. Called out at night to go up to firing line mend blown up paraphet on the outside plenty bullets about.
Entry.147: Easy day afternoon detailed again for gas guard, went on 6 to 8 shift and 12 till 2 plenty machine gun bullets flying around. First week in trenches enough as good as a feast.
Entry.148: Gas guard all day came off 6. Went up to stand too in firing line then went over paraphet into No Mans Land inspecting our own barb wire.
Entry.149: After being up all night went down to Dead Dog Avenue in the morning on fatigue, afternoon slept, night time packed up dead mens clothes rifles, etc. @ Ammunition dump.
Entry.150: Had a day off. Afternoon went up to firing line on duty pretty well all the time.
Entry.151: Usual trench work morningafternoon then remained in bay during bombardment another artillery duel in the night couple of casualties in 31st Battalion.
Entry.152: Morning one hours duty in trench afternoon fatigue work mate fingers blown off, night went out in No Mans land putting lime on dead men and gathering their personnel effects.
Entry.153: Mate wounded by sniper in morning while sitting on paraphet, fatigue again in afternoon. Given a bit of kid stakes for going out into No Mans land the night before.
Entry.154: Morning guard as usual, Germans blew up mine close to our paraphet daylight shook everything, two miners blown to pieces another wounded, fatigue work afternoon for three hours. Our miners blew up mine close to German trench late in afternoon.
Entry.155: Usual day in trenches what looked like scrap going on away to the left between eleven and twelve @ night.
Entry.156: Morning usual trench work, afternoon relieved by the 29th Battalion after fifteen days in trenches went back to old billet where we left.
Entry.157: Morning went down to Bac-St-Maur for hot bath andchange of clothes. Afternoon inspection by Colonel. Announced that A.M.C. man awarded Military Medal.
Entry.158: Fatigue in trenches in morning, afternoon rifle inspection, volunteers called for raiding party.
Entry.159: Fatigue trenches nothing doing came home again to billett afternoon usual inspection. Started to rain during day.
Entry.160: Wet day again, went up on fatigue to trenches worked in morning, came back to billet. Afternoon went Bac-St-Maur for prisoner. That night Coy left to train for raiding party.
Entry.161:
Morning fatigue work laying telephone wires, afternoon rifle inspection. After tea went down to Bac-St-Maur. 

Only a private soldier
Only a mother's son
On the field of Battle
His Duty he has done.
Entry.162: Morning helped cook get breakfast after that went to Junction Post did rifle and bayonet drill morning and afternoon.
Entry.163: Physical drill before breakfast afterwards rifle and bayonet drill then games, sprained ankle, off drill all afternoon from same.
Entry.164: Morning went to Doctor with wrenched ankle got two days off duty.
Entry.166: Off duty with ankle. Fritz shelled pretty strong in the morning.
Entry.167: Still off duty issued with new helmet afternoon orders to get ready to march.
Entry.168: Morning nothing doing afternoon went down to Bac-St-Maur still weak ankle.
Entry.169: Morning nothing in work line went down to Bac-St-Maur to Div. baths for clean up, afternoon and night artillery bombarded enemys trenches.
Entry.170:
Revelle three a.m. left Junction Post full marching order for
Lamen
 Lamotte 12½ miles arrived pretty well done up camped in tents, rained all day and night.
Entry.171: Rained all day morning Battalion parade afternoon visited the wood nightime went for a walk to the village of Lamotte.
Entry.172: Morning and afternoon practice in wood fighting. Nightime received letter from a cousin in Egypt also one from London about wounded mate nothing known.
Entry.173: Cooks fatigue all day night time horse picket for transport horses all night.
Entry.174: Cameoff picket seven did nothing morning, afternoon attended sports, after tea was paid 40 francs then went up to Lamotte.
Entry.175: Morning church service for C.E. Guard of Honour of forty went to Sailly to witness medals given for bravery in stunt of
Entry.176: R.S.M. of 31st received D.C.M. four or five medals given to this battalion, afternoon went to Lamotte all afternoon.
Entry.177:
Wood fighting all day. Received letter from Aunt in morning, afternoon same drill, night time went up to Lamotte had a shave lady barber.

Tuesday
Rained all day morning route march afternoon instructions in wood fighting, night time went up to village of Lamotte.
Entry.178: Instructions all day on trench life and gas attacks, night time went into Lamotte village.
Entry.179: Left La Motte about nine en route for Bac-St-Maur, arrived and stopped in a dirty billet about four, marched about fifteen miles passed through Merville, Estairs, Sailly, Bac-St-Maur outskirts.
Entry.180: Fatigue up in the front line of trenches till one o'clock afternoon went down to Divisional Baths had a bath and got a change of clothes.
Entry.181: Fatigue up in front line in morning, afternoon rifle and gas bag inspections.
Entry.182: Went up to firing Line on fatigue until one o'clock as usual got up before daylight, after tea wrote two letters, one home one to a relation.
Entry.183: Day off did nothing morning, afternoon went down to Bac-St-Maur for bath and change of clothes came back and shifted to a cleaner billet near Fleaurbaix .
Entry.184: Fatigue morning up in supports. Mounted gas and aeroplane guard six o'clock second relief. Strong bombardment during night for a while.
Entry.186: Fatigue work in support in morning till one o'clock, afternoon usual inspection, started to rain night time.
Entry.187:
Friday 15 
Sick all day went to Doctor got medicine marked off duty for day pretty crook night before. Leave for England reported about to take place.
Entry.188: Lay in in morning afterwards no work got paid forty francs. Afternoon went down to Bac-St-Maur for bath and change of clothes.
Entry.189: Missed fatigue nothing doing all day
Entry.190: Went out fatigue did nothing on account of rain got wet through went on guard eight o'clock @ night very cold and miserable.
Entry.191: On guard until six in afternoon.
Entry.192: Fatigue work up in supports, afternoon received order to get ready to go to Armentieres.
Entry.193: Left Fleurbaix for Armenteries nine o'clock arrived at billet about half past ten got issued with new respritator afterwards went for look round city which was badly knocked about nearly all people have gone and left belongings.
Entry.194: Left Armentieres half past eight arrived trenches eleven relieved the 4th Seaforth Highlanders went on gas and observation duty @ seven, stand too all night, very cold and quiet on this sector big bombardment and raid further down.
Entry.195: Came off gas and observation guard seven did water fatigue then went out in No Mans Land over the wire for five hours, bitterly cold and damp, nearly stopped one of our own bullets.
Entry.196: Slept all morning till dinnertime, afternoon fatigue for two hours. Patrolled trenches all night, cold as usual and fairly quiet.
Entry.197: Slept in morning not feeling to good, afternoon did no fatigue shifted quarters six o'clock to go on guard, what sounded like bomb fight with patrols occured out in No Mans Land during night.
Entry.198: Still on guard all through night fairly quiet until nearly two in morning then bullet missed head by about a foot.
Entry.199: Still on guard duty very cold night also foggy.
Entry.200:
Shifted down to supports in morning, afternoon went down to Armentieres for a bath just got in heart of city when German shells fell about one hundred yards from us, ran for our lives took refuge in an old brewery lots of men, women and children killed also some of our soldiers.

September -
Entry.201: Morning went for rations, afternoon bit of rest, night time engineers fatigue.
Entry.202: Afternoon went through gas test, morning did fatigue around dug outs.
Entry.203: Morning engineers fatigue up in front line, afternoon had a rest.
Entry.204: Morning fatigue till one o'clock carrying timber, afternoon slept night time ration fatigue.
Entry.205: Morning fatigue firing line got pigeon bombed one man killed. Paid forty francs in afternoon, night time pulled out of bed for fatigue pushing timber up to the firing line until midnight.
Entry.206: Shifted out of supports to another part in the rain wandering around like lost sheep all day then put on guard. Enemy very lively with minnieslate in afternoon, no one hurt, tucker getting very light.
Entry.207: Still on permanent guard, very bleak and wet, gas attack @ night several men gassed. Our own shells also lobbing very close.
Entry.208:
Still on guard showery throughout day, nightime gas sent over then bombardment then a raid reported failure, lot wounded officer killed. 
German prisoner captured in our firing line.
Entry.209: On guard miserable day got word to pack up to go away to train. Left trenches stayed outside Armentieres.
Entry.210: Fell in in morning then went into Armentieres all day stayed out till night time had a good time with Northumberland Fusiliers.
Entry.211: Instructions in hand grenade throwing in morning, afternoon bayonet and physical work, night time went to Y.M.C.A. and pictures at Industrial College Buildings.
Entry.212: Bayonet and physical drill during morning, afternoon raid instructions and live bomb throwing, nightime stroll round city very quiet.
Entry.213: Morning raid instructions, afternoon lecture on bombs, nightime patrol No Mans Land cutting wire.
Entry.214:
Instructions during day, nightime raided enemy trenches went across No Mans Land
ab
 charged about eight, got in trenches for about twenty minutes, lots of Germans killed, three of our own, about sixteen wounded, got a souvenier cap.
Entry.215: Had a bit of a rest. Congratulated by two Generals on the successful raid,afternoon brigade moved out per motor lorry to near Hazerbrouk new reinforcements joined us up, remains of our chaps who fell in raid buried Armentieres.
Entry.216: Morning fell in for inspection and drafted into platoons, afternoon wenton route march, night time went into Strazelle for a look round.
Entry.217: Morning parade as usual, afternoon went on parade to witness decorations for bravery in the raid presented by General Godley, all staff present. Afterwards went into Hazerbrouck nice place fair size very quiet.
Entry.218: Morning went down and did a bit of fatigue work in fish alley nothing to eat till two o'clock, night time went for meat to Thistle dump, had a rotten time falling over shell holes in dark, arrived back very tired and slept till about seven.
Entry.219: Left billet on the way to the Somme, marched through Strazelle, arrived @ Bailleul dinner time then entrained, travelled till midnight then got out @ some unknown place and marched seven miles to Yaucourt then rested all day and went to another village for a walk.
Entry.220: Still @ Yaucourt all day, went for a walk to Bussus.
Entry.221: Left Yaucourt early, marched four miles then got in French motor lorries riding nearly all day, passed through Amiens, arrived @ some village near nightfall bitterly cold, plenty of soldiers about.
Entry.222: Marched off again towards firing line, saw thousands of men and horses moving coming and going, camped about seven miles from firing line.
Entry.223: Left camp after dinner to go into supports line on the Somme passed through row after row of firing guns, got to support about five o'clock, started cleaning trench, sat up all night bitterly cold, guns kept up firing continously without break the whole time, enemy replied occassionally.
Entry.224: Morning did a little fatigue work, afternoon drill and lecture on future fighting, nightime went for a walk with a couple of mates, pay day but never went for any.
Entry.225: Continued on with meal, arrived nearly done at B. Hqrs. Men had nothing to eat all day, place absolutely a quagmire, mud and slush. Went on guard for two hours @ night, got hit by a bit of shrapnel bitterly cold, slept in enemy dugout.
Entry.226: Still in supports, enemy continually shelling, arm very sore from hit previous night, couple of men killed, several wounded by a shell, one meal all day, very cold and miserable.
Entry.227: Moved out of supports up to firing line in morning, had to plough a way through mud, guard during day, nightime trench digging and guard again, no sleep, no dugouts to sleep in and very little to eat.
Entry.228: Still in front line looking forward to getting relieved. Afternoon heavily bombarded by the enemy, couple of casualties, rained, made things very miserable, rotten cold night.
Entry.229: Got in another trench bombardment all day, one man killed another wounded, relieved at night, spent the whole night marching back through mud, got lost somewhere.
Entry.230:
Arrived in tired and weary, state in camp properly fagged out, had a spell all day, got a letter from Sydney.

October -
Entry.231: Miserable day started to rain got everything saturated, had to liein wet all night.
Entry.232: Went on fatigue morning, afternoon went back to trenches, spent a cold miserable night standing in a wet trench.
Entry.233: Still in same place after spending a most miserable night, shelled heavily by the enemy during day, many casualties, fatigue @ nightime.
Entry.234: Still in same trench, guard at nightime, still having a cold and miserable time.
Entry.235: Still in trench, showery during daytime, heavy shelled again day and shrapnel @ night, a few casualties, carried dead man down for burial @ nightime.
Entry.236: In trenches all day, heavily shelled by shrapnel, relieved @ night by 23rd Batt., walked all best part of night through mud and rain to Montaban Wood.
Entry.237: Left Montaban Wood midday, walked to Fricourt, arrived dead beat about dusk.
Entry.238: Left Fricourt for Ducourt, arrived about midday sore footed fairly miserable place, plenty of troops passing through.
Entry.239: Left Ducourt after dinner, marched to Ville-Sous-Corbie then got in big French Motor lorries, arrived @ another village half past seven, passed through Amiens.
Entry.240: Had an easy day in village of St Vasst-en-Chaussee. Still bad feet promised leave again also complete issue of clothes and pay.
Entry.241: Morning paraded to Doctor with bad feet, was given pills, afternoon route march, fell out on account of bad feet.
Entry.242: Morning drill, afternoon nothing nightime went to Vigincourt .
Entry.243: Paraded to Doctor again with bad feet same result got pills and light duty, issued with sheep skin vest, paid fifty five francs.
Entry.244: Cooks fatigue morning and after dinner, night time went to Vigincourt, went to Church there, returned about eight o'clock. Remainder of 8th Brigade inspected by General Birdwood during morning service.
Entry.245: Usual days work, issued with socks and gloves.
Entry.246: Morning route march, afternoon kit inspection.
Entry.247: Went to Amiens, visited Cathedral, lovely building, wandered around city all day, arrived home to Vast about six @night by motor lorry and cart.
Entry.248: Morning physical drill and bayonet exercise, afternoon did nothing.
Entry.249: Usual drill morning, afternoon before O.C. charged with being A.W.L. charged dismissed. Got orders to prepare to leave.
Entry.250: Up before daylight in the snow for the first time, marched along road then got in French motor lorry, arrived @ village eleven, stayed remainder day and night, passed through Amiens.
Entry.251: Up early again, left village half past eleven for firing line, arrived huts near Mametz Wood at dusk, plenty of mud and slush about also cold.
Entry.252: Left huts and arrived @ or near Trones Wood near dark, very cold and boggy.
Entry.253: Left afternoon for trenches about half past two arrived at trenches and relieved Coldstream Guards about seven, put in a cold miserable night as usual. Some casualties coming in.
Entry.254: Trenches all day, saw enemy aeroplane brought down, night time did work in sap when enemy suddenly bombarded heavily, rushed back and stood too. Bombarded again two in morning also sent over gas shells.
Entry.255: Very quiet all day, relieved at night by 29th who were caught in heavy barage of fire, seven killed, one of ours killed, arrived huts near Mametz Wood properly done up.
Entry.256: Arrived nearly daylight from trenches, slept all day.
Entry.257: Fatigue morning in rain issued issued with gum boots, afternoon moved out in rain to Trones Wood, put in fairly miserable night.
Entry.258: Went up to Divisional Headquarters without breakfast, on fatigue all day digging foundations for huts.
Entry.259: Still on Headquarters fatigue, saw aeroplane come down in flames one of our own.
Entry.262: Headquarters fatigue, severe frost in morning bitterly cold.
Entry.266: till Headquarters fatigue, met an old schoolmate.
Entry.267: Reville five morning pushing duck boards up tram line, same again five in afternoon.
Entry.268: Got orders to move to firing line, left twelve arrive Rowe trench carried duck boards to front trench, came back to Rose trench then shifted to Needle Dump.
Entry.269: Needle Dump all day putting up dug outs, moved out at night to support trench, placed on sentry duty.
Entry.270: Still on Sentry duty in support trench, moved to front trench in afternoon. Raid during night heavy bombardment.
Entry.271: Front line all day, started to rain, got relieved by 32nd, very rough time coming out in mud got bogged.
Entry.272: Arrived Rose trench early morning from front trench wet through. Stayed trench all day, moved back to Camp that night, arrived there about ten o'clock.
Entry.274: Did fatigue work all day pushing up hut in arterial.
Entry.276: Fatigue work started five a.m. ceased 8 o'clock, received four letters.
Entry.278: Same work again started four o'clock knocked off ten o'clock.
Entry.281: A couple of hours fatigue nightime.
Entry.282: Moved out of camp to Dernacourt arrived about midday, went into billets, met old mate 20th Batt.
Entry.283: Morning did nothing, afternoon had a parade, list of shortages taken.
Entry.284: Had a spell, shortages again taken, had a bath and change of clothes @ Meaulte.
Entry.285: March in mud before breakfast afterwards rifle inspection and inspected by new D. Commander, afternoon fatigue.
Entry.287: Went church parade morning, dinner greasy stew, sodden plum pudding, bitterly cold day, afternoon off.
Entry.288: Physical drill morningrifle inspection after breakfast, afternoon route march.
Entry.291:
Physical drill
rifle
 company drillroute march afternoon.
Entry.293: After breakfast bayonet drill, route march afternoon past Beurie.
Entry.294:
Slept in till breakfast after that went
on route march
church parade then gas helmit inspection afternoon went for
work
 walk to Albert had a look at leaning tower, came back at dusk. Thus finished the year 1916. Got paid thirty francs.
